Congratulations to HMC-1‚Äôs 2020 Student Law Academy graduates!

Daniels L., Muhammad S., and Assaf L., three Ruskin High School students, joined by eight other high school students from the Kansas City metropolitan area, successfully completed the SLA 2020 virtual two-month program.

SLA is a partnership with PREP-KC and the Kansas City Metropolitan Bar Foundation offering 6-week paid internships to students interested in careers in law. Throughout their time in the program, SLA Scholars learned from legal professionals via interactive sessions, discussions, and special projects. They virtually visited courts, witnessed dockets, depositions, and learned about the legal system and careers in the law.

A special thank you to our partners for helping our students learn more about their passions and interests in a hands-on, collaborative and engaging way.

Congratulations again to our students, we are so proud of you and can‚Äôt wait to see how you apply what you've learned this summer in the 2020-21 school year #HMC1Proud!

To learn more about the SLA program, visit: https://bit.ly/2QdPJkl

2nd grade teacher Jennifer Fry was inspired by educator Corinthian Clay Nutter.

Ms. Nutter taught at Walker Elementary School in Merriam, a segregated school known for its run down exterior and lack of indoor plumbing. In 1947, a new school was built, but when enrollment came along, African American students were denied access to the new school. In protest, Ms. Nutter organized a home school for children in her community, holding class in church basements and neighborhood living rooms. She also joined a group of individuals who built a case against the district and sued the state.

‚ÄúHer fundamental principle was we teach children. We have to do what is right for all children because they all deserve it. We have to teach them that through education, they will have endless possibilities and opportunities.‚Äù

Her parents also stressed the importance of getting an education because they were not able to complete theirs; they had to work in the cotton fields.

Dru Williams, an HMC-1 instructional coach, listed basketball player Bill Russell as his biggest influence in African American history. Russell had a team-first mentality and refused to be the victim of any abuse.

Russell‚Äôs experiences resonated with Williams in two ways. First, Williams was typically the only football, basketball, baseball, or track athlete of color in his town growing up. Williams said he could have played victim many times, but never thought that route would make it easier for himself or anyone after him.

Secondly, Russell was never a guy who needed the spotlight; he just wanted his team to achieve greatness. Williams feels the same about his work at HMC-1. At every level of his career, he has always wanted to provide the absolute best for his student so they could reach a high standard. Williams now works to ensure HMC-1 teachers have what they need to help their students reach high standards, not only in academic achievements, but in learning who they are and what they can become.

post_text: Our 1st It's On Me recipient is Nurse Gloria Schallert. Ms. Shallert works to not only help organize the extra clothing for students at Ingels Elementary, but has gone out of her way to provide essential pieces. She also offers to wash students' clothing in the building's washer and dryer when needed. Ingels students know when they step into the nurse's office, they will be met by a loving, comforting soul. #HMC1Together #ItsOnMe
